To keep this short and simple, since very few if anyone will read it, and I tend to ramble and rant randomly, I'll simply list a few ways this title compares with similar games, from my perspective.  I have played most of the TR games since the original on the playstation. I always enjoy them to at least some extent, but often gave up on finishing them, rather than look up walkthroughs and strain my eyes and/or nerves for hours and hours. This game, however, I truly enjoyed. I watched part of one video walkthrough, because of confusion, but it was my mistake as I simply wasn't fully aware of the inventory system (since I had the item the entire time, but am quite used to notifications these days.) I played on the easiest difficulty, but that almost exclusively affects combat. The new functions available made the fighting even easier at times, but also tempting to fool around with, resulting in Lara's untimely demise more than a few times. To be honest, I tend to dislike the combat systems of tomb raider games most of the time, but looking back I can clearly state that if they had always had some of these abilities in earlier titles, especially the dedicated melee/spinkick/jumpkick/etc, I would have enjoyed them all much more. To me, the best parts of this 'original/non-reboot' Tomb Raider series, was the adventure aspect. Earlier titles varied greatly in their adventure/puzzle/combat ratio(s) but never quite like this game. Some was frustrating, even a couple parts that took dozens of attempts, but the issues were mainly my own.  All things considered, the puzzles were quite easy, levels often quite linear, and plot twists that weren't often surprising. But the most important thing about each of those 'negatives' is if you are comparing this game with others that specialize in one or two aspects. Despite simplicity at times, the puzzles often required thought, patience, and were fun. Any 'linear' issues are irrelevant to me for this game, as it was more of an interactive movie, not an open world RPG. And the story, despite it not being perfect, and often described as anti-climactic, felt more real and understandable than some big end fight. tl;dr. enjoy it for what it is.

So far I am really enjoying this entry, but I am old and played the originals when they came out. I have also already played 2013 and that being said never really felt like it was a true 'TR' game, it just missed the mark for puzzles and vibes in my opinion. Underworld hits the nostalgia button just right, though I was sad to see they added the hints for people too lazy to figure it out for themselves. I've learned alot about Lara Croft during this adventure- mainly that she enjoys ancient tomato soup and playing D&D. Despite the glitches, clipping and dated graphics I would recommend this to anyone who enjoys the series; unless you thought 2013 was amazing, then maybe you should just get Uncharted instead.

I enjoyed the story and I really enjoyed the parkour type places in the game. They added a couple new jumping mechanics on top of the ones from tomb raider legend. The puzzles were well designed as I felt challenged, taking a while to figure them out, but no so frustrating that I wanted to give up.  Here comes the big BUT.  They didn't fix the terrible camera tracking while climbing. You often find yourself having to blindly jump backwards because the camera angle wont allow you to turn far enough to see where to jump to next.  Also, a lot of the time throughout the climbing bits of the game I found Lara didn't respond to where I wanted to jump to and would often just jump off in some random direction resulting in a falling death. Which did get pretty frustrating, especially if you've been climbing for some time and been making progress.  Overall, I enjoyed parts of the game, but it got pretty frustrating at some points with poor mechanics.

It's not a bad game, but they keep trying to add new stuff that doesn't work. After finishing TR : Legend ( a somewhat smooth but short experience ) I wanted to give this one another try. Could never finish it because most of the time I end up ragequiting, and here is why :  - the controls sucks sometimes and Lara dies - the balancing mechanics on wooden beams sucks and Lara dies - the wall multi-jump mechanics doesn't work and you have to start over, or Lara dies - the headshot system sucks and is completely useless - you have to fight the camera constantly, and Lara dies - Ai is mindless or berserk - the save system sucks  In fact this game could have been called Tomb Raider : Lara dies a lot. I died more time in the 2 first levels than in the entire Legend game, only due to bad controls, camera, or design. Maybe it's a good thing that they rebooted the series with the 2013 TR, because the next 'normal' TR game would have been a real mess full of useless gameplay mechanics just for the sake of adding something new, even if it doesn't work.  At least Lara looks good, when she doesn't die. Only play it if you can overcome the bad gamedesign.

I have to say that I don't recommend this game. The mechanics need more polish. One example is one jump might appear close enough, but since you're not supposed to go there, you'll fall and die. You will successfully leap across a larger gap if you are meant to go that route. This kind of trial an error sucks. There is a major physics glitch that nearly prevents you from completing the game. (Vsync helps.) You will be manually adjusting the camera almost constantly to undo the angles it automatically chooses. Combat is really an annoying part of the game.  What was good? The puzzles and climbing parts were fun. Unfortunately, everything else that surrounds the core gameplay to make it a more fleshed out game ends up detracting from the enjoyment of the game. That, coupled with the poor mechanics and glitches, ruins the game overall.

I played just 2 or 3 minutes effectively and cannot say anything about in-depth gameplay or story, but one thing already ruined the game no matter how good those may be: The controls. I'm not sure how it acts on controllers, i suspect no better though. You might have had some terrible experiences with the other, newer tomb raider games which all have poor controls, but this is a new dimension of 'f***ed up'. I'm playing video games for fifteen years now, several hours per day, and I've never encountered a game that made me nauseous so far. Until now. The little fact that the camera automatically tries to adapt to your character movement (which is glitchy already) and tries to overwrite your controls leads to an immense clusterf*** of camera movements. I proceeded in the game until you have to pull open the door with the grappling hook before I had to quit and empty my stomach in the bathroom.  I'll see if I can find a workaround for this (i.e. blocking this particular behaviour somehow), but since the game does not offer any solution or setting regarding this, it's definitely a reason not to buy the game.

I was not a Tomb Raider fan before the entire Crystal Dynamics trilogy (Legend, Anniversary, Underworld), but their take on the franchise contains some ludicrous stories well told and some hair-tearing puzzles cleverly designed. Underworld is the standout. It's the most linear of the bunch (which means both less complexity and less tedium), but at the same time achieves a sense of epic scale not matched by the others. It's the little things Crystal Dynamics does so right - the art design is - as always - stupendous, the sound design some of the best in gaming...it'll take you places other games haven't even bothered to try...and oh, that climax...the final battle is a truly incredible, constantly shifting puzzle/firefight that will always hold a special place in my gamer heart. I highly recommend buying TR: Legend and Underworld in a sale, since the story links so well...as well as Anniversary, if you've got a lot of patience.

On my computer the framerates were so fast that I ran into playability issues. I was so stressed out because whenever I would pick up a block and try to set it down it would fly hundreds of feet in random directions. So I was reading some tech support forums and found that some people were saying that if they turned the graphic settings or anti aliasing all the way up, it seemed to help but not cure the issue. This got me thinking. Maybe it has to do with framerate?   I usually display my framerate in an OSD with a monitoring app and realized that I was getting hundreds of frames per second even with the graphics and AA settings maxed out. So I started experimenting with VSYNC. This fixed the issue.   Turn on VSYNC to solve most playability issues.   It has been a fun game, the graphics are great, and Laura is hot as ever.

Pretty enjoyable game! Decided to finally play through it after putting if off for a few years. Combat is pretty meh but luckily there's not a huge amount of it, and without shedding any spoilers it get's pretty fun later on. The environments the game takes you through are pretty breathtaking for their day in design, scale and scope, plus they all are filled with puzzles and climbing routes that sometimes span the entire level. Didn't take me too long to complete, maybe 8 hours or so. A couple of frustrating areas had me looking at a walkthrough for pointers, including the end sequence which was rather confusing at times. I'd highly recommend it if you like adventure games and exploration - if you can pardon the somewhat crazy magical story. Also Lara is looking her best which doesn't harm :) Underworld is under-rated.

Tomb Raider Underworld wraps up the first reboot trilogy, tying loose ends of Legend and including the events of Anniversary. The story is darker and good. The graphics are good and the music epic at times. And the gameplay is what you would expect, with fluid controls for exploration and puzzle solving, once again in tombs. The combat is still average though. The length is somewhere between Legend and Anniversary. A worth sequel to two great titles. If you liked those, you'll like this one.
